docs.description:
Execute a sequence of operations.
Wraps `@openfn/language-common/execute`, and prepends initial state for DuckDB.

tags.title: example
tags.description:
execute(
  query('SELECT * FROM my_table'),
  insert('users', { name: 'John', age: 30 })
)(state)

docs.description: Execute a SQL statement

tags.title: param
tags.description: The SQL query as a string or function
tags.name: sqlQuery

tags.title: state
tags.description: {object} - Returns query results in state.data and response metadata in state.response

docs.description:
Picks out a single value from source data.
If a JSONPath returns more than one value for the reference, the first
item will be returned.
Ensures a path points at the data.

Picks out a single value from the source data objectâ€”usually `state.data`.
If a JSONPath returns more than one value for the reference, the first
item will be returned.
Picks out the last reference value from source data.

Iterates over an array of items and invokes an operation upon each one, where the state
object is _scoped_ so that state.data is the item under iteration.
The rest of the state object is untouched and can be referenced as usual.
You can pass an array directly, or use lazy state or a JSONPath string to
reference a slice of state.

tags.title: example
tags.caption: Using lazy state ($) to iterate over items in state.data and pass each into an "insert" operation

tags.title: example
tags.caption: Iterate over items in state.data and pass each one into an "insert" operation

tags.title: example
tags.caption: Using JSON path to iterate over items in state.data and pass each one into an "insert" operation

tags.title: param
tags.description: The operation needed to be repeated.
tags.name: operation

docs.description: Turns an array into a string, separated by X.

Sets a cursor property on state.
Supports natural language dates like `now`, `today`, `yesterday`, `n hours ago`, `n days ago`, and `start`,
which will be converted relative to the environment (ie, the Lightning or CLI locale). Custom timezones
are not yet supported.
You can provide a formatter to customise the final cursor value, which is useful for normalising
different inputs. The custom formatter runs after natural language date conversion.
See the usage guide at {@link https://docs.openfn.org/documentation/jobs/job-writing-guide#using-cursors}

tags.title: example
tags.caption: Use a cursor from state if present, or else use the default value

tags.title: param
tags.description: the cursor value. Usually an ISO date, natural language date, or page number
tags.name: value

tags.title: param
tags.description: set the cursor key. Will persist through the whole run.
tags.name: options.key

tags.title: param
tags.description: the value to use if value is falsy
tags.name: options.defaultValue

tags.title: param
tags.description: custom formatter for the final cursor value
tags.name: options.format

tags.name: operation

docs.description:
Iterates over a collection of items and returns a new array of mapped values,
like Javascript's `Array.map()` function.

Each item in the source array will be passed into the callback function. The returned value
will be added to the new array. The callback is passed the original item, the current index
in the source array (ie, the nth item number), and the state object.

Writes a new array to `state.data` with transformed values.c array.

tags.title: example
tags.caption: Transform an array of items in state

tags.title: example
tags.caption: Map items asynchronously (e.g. fetch extra info)

tags.title: param
tags.description: An array of items or a a JSONPath string which points to an array of items.
tags.name: path

tags.title: param
tags.description: The mapping function, invoked with `(data, index, state)` for each item in the array.
tags.name: callback
